text: A look at efforts to help animals safely cross the highway. Also in this edition: a profile of Kevin Durant, and why we’re all talking about U.F.O.s.

headline: Why Leaving the Nest Is Harder the Second Time Around
text: For Tiana Mason, a 26-year-old research assistant at Boston University, moving back to New Jersey to live with her parents during the pandemic was hard at first. But that didn’t compare to the overwhelming anxiety she felt several months later after she left the nest again to go back to Boston.

headline: Review: Connection, Interrupted, in ‘Communion’
text: Last March, I booked tickets to see “The Headlands,” a new play by Christopher Chen. A few days later, live theater vanished like some awful magic act. I never made it to that show. But now Chen, a high-concept playwright with a vertiginous approach to dramatic structure, has created a new one, “Communion,” a clever and chilly digital wisp produced by the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco and experienced on Zoom. To see it, as in-person performances prepare to return elsewhere, provides a dizzy kind of symmetry.

headline: How to Quiet Your Inner Critic
text: Grant Snider offers a visual guide to telling that voice inside your head to shut it.

headline: Reimagining the Aftermath of a Wartime Attack
text: Francis Spufford’s new novel, “Light Perpetual,” is rooted in a real event: the rocket attack on a Woolworth’s in London, killing 168 people, toward the end of World War II. Spufford fictionalizes the tragedy and invents five children who survive it, trailing them through the ensuing decades to discover all they might have done and seen had they lived. On this week’s podcast, Spufford says that he settled on this real-life incident for intentionally arbitrary reasons.

headline: The Jobs Report Takeaway: A Huge Reallocation of People and Work Is Underway
text: Friday’s news about the 559,000 jobs added in May wasn’t far off market expectations, but it is a far cry from the once-anticipated V-shaped recovery that would have meant millions of people a month pouring back into their old jobs. The economy has not bounced back to prepandemic employment levels, even as G.D.P. effectively has.

headline: A Million Years of Data Confirms: Monsoons Are Likely to Get Worse
text: Global warming is likely to make India’s monsoon season wetter and more dangerous, new research suggests.

headline: Wonking Out: Do Hiring Headaches Imply a Labor Shortage?
text: This article is a wonky edition of Paul Krugman’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it.

headline: Susan Cole, Advocate for Traumatized Children, Dies at 72
text: At a time when many school officials thought the best way to deal with problematic students was to suspend or expel them, Susan F. Cole realized what may seem obvious now: Sometimes, trouble at school meant trauma at home.

headline: Naomi Osaka: Celebrities, the Media and Mental Health
text: To the Editor:

headline: National Black Theater Plans Next Act in a New Harlem High-Rise
text: It was more than 50 years ago that Barbara Ann Teer rented space in a building at 125th Street and Fifth Avenue in Harlem that would serve as the home of a nascent organization called National Black Theater.

headline: President Biden, the Clock Is Ticking to Rescind a Trump Immigration Policy
text: MIAMI — In the eyes of Betty Mejía, President Biden and former President Donald Trump are one and the same: Both have deported her. In the last year Ms. Mejía, who is from Honduras, tried six times to cross into the United States illegally with her son and daughter, only to be detained and deported back to Mexico each time. For her, and many other immigrants like her, nothing at the border has changed between administrations.

headline: Congress Needs to Defend Vote Counting, Not Just Vote Casting
text: Republican-controlled state legislatures are whittling away at the integrity of electoral democracy in the United States, rushing to pass laws that make it harder for Americans to vote and easier for partisans to tamper with election results.

headline: Four Ways This Summer Is a Huge Test for Movie Theaters
text: The first sign that moviegoers were ready to return to theaters came when “Godzilla vs. Kong” stomped into cinemas at the end of March. Even though it also streamed on HBO Max, the movie made $98 million in North American theaters and $436 million worldwide. That was welcome news after a pandemic year that was terrible for movie theaters.

headline: Scott Stringer Is Accused of Sexual Misconduct by 2nd Woman
text: Five weeks after an allegation of unwanted sexual advances upended Scott M. Stringer’s New York City mayoral campaign, a second woman is accusing him of sexual harassment and making unwanted advances when she said she worked for Mr. Stringer nearly three decades ago.

headline: Why Are So Many Children in Brazil Dying From Covid-19?
text: In the modern history of catastrophic infectious diseases in Brazil, children often suffer the most in terms of deaths and disability. When dengue epidemics emerged in Brazil in 2007 and 2008, children accounted for more than half of the fatalities. When pregnant women became infected with the Zika virus during an epidemic that began in 2015, more than 1,600 Brazilians were born with devastating microcephaly, far more than in any other nation. Respiratory viruses continue to disproportionately affect Brazil’s children, while hookworms and other intestinal parasites stunt childhood growth and development, especially in poor rural areas.

headline: Curator Joy Bivins Is Named New Director of the Schomburg Center
text: Joy Bivins, who joined the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem last year, has been named director of the center.

headline: For State Department’s No. 2, Another Turn at High-Stakes Diplomacy
text: WASHINGTON — Six years ago, the American diplomat Wendy R. Sherman made her mark on the world stage by negotiating a landmark nuclear deal with Iran. Reviving that agreement, after the Trump administration all but scuttled it, is a top priority for President Biden.

headline: Board of Washington and Lee University Votes to Keep Lee’s Name
text: Washington and Lee University, the private liberal arts school in Virginia, will not change its name after a monthslong review over whether to remove its reference to the Confederate general Robert E. Lee, the school announced on Friday.

headline: Senior Trump Organization Official Testifies Before Grand Jury
text: A senior finance executive at Donald J. Trump’s family business has testified before a state grand jury in Manhattan as prosecutors ramp up their investigation of Mr. Trump and his company, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: What It’s Like to Be a Teenage Mom During the Pandemic
text: At first, Amya Noble never imagined she might be pregnant. She was 16, a sophomore in high school, and had no plans to raise a child.

headline: Bipartisan Infrastructure Talks Recall Heated Health Care Summer of 2009
text: WASHINGTON — The heated summer of hostile town hall events and death-panel scare tactics was bleeding into the fall of 2009, and still, bipartisan negotiations over what would become the Affordable Care Act dragged on.

headline: How to Prepare for Hurricane Season and Evacuations
text: Be ready for another season of above-normal hurricane activity in the Atlantic.

headline: For Lemon Curd in Less Than 10 Minutes, Use Your Microwave
text: Recipes for microwave lemon curd have been around since the 1980s. But it took an Instagram post in 2021 to get me to try it.

headline: It’s 2021. Why Is ‘Supermom’ Still Around?
text: — Letty Cottin Pogrebin, a founding editor of Ms. magazine

headline: Staples returns to Office Depot with a $1 billion offer for its consumer business.
text: Staples isn’t giving up its quest for Office Depot.

headline: Teens Are Rarely Hospitalized With Covid, but Cases Can Be Severe
text: Since the start of the pandemic, very few adolescents have become ill enough with Covid-19 to be hospitalized. But of those who did, about one-third were admitted to intensive care units, and 5 percent required ventilators, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported on Friday.

headline: What to Do This Weekend
text: Welcome. Will this summer be a wild, maskless frolic, a Roaring ’20s montage of window sashes flung open, giddy reunions, spontaneous making out with strangers? In her essay for this week’s Times Magazine, the Canadian writer Mireille Silcoff examines how advertising has fueled the notion that the pandemic’s end will inevitably lead to a collective explosion of “MULT,” or “Making Up for Lost Time.” While a viral gum ad depicts a “multigenerational cuddle puddle — a pandemonium of sweatpants askew and unshaven body parts and sprinklers gone wild,” Silcoff observes that the “pain and wisdom seeded by the past year are fragile” and “need to be introduced back into the world carefully.”

headline: Essential Strategies to Prevent Drowning
text: Two years ago, I wrote about strategies to prevent drowning deaths in young children, especially in the two age groups where those deaths spike, the toddlers and the adolescents. It’s a perennial topic for those who write about children’s health, because drowning is such a major risk for both those ages — the leading preventable cause of death in children from 1 to 4, and then again in adolescents, especially boys, where it’s the second-most-common cause of preventable deaths from 15 to 19, after car accidents.

headline: Cardinal Offers Resignation Over Church Sexual Abuse
text: Cardinal Reinhard Marx, a leading figure in Germany’s Roman Catholic Church, said on Friday that he had offered his resignation to share in taking collective responsibility for sexual abuses by priests.

headline: As Dictators Target Citizens Abroad, Few Safe Spaces Remain
text: Tahir Imin knew that romances sometimes end. So he did not expect the long arm of global authoritarianism when the woman he had been planning to marry broke things off in March.

headline: The 17 Best Recipes Our Food Staff Cooked Last Month
text: The beauty of May is that it brings with it unadulterated spring weather. Cool days may appear from time to time, but there’s nary a whisper of the bitter cold. Produce, like hope, springs eternal, and nowhere was that clearer than on our plates. Last month, The New York Times Food and Cooking staff went wild in the face of bright flavors, favoring herbs, greens and ripe, succulent fruit over the slightly more staid flavors of cold weather cooking. Here are some of the meals we made in May.

headline: Love Letter: A Real-Life Romance Novel
text: When Kimberlee Stevenson picked up a copy of “Until I Saw Your Smile” by the romance writer J.J. Murray in 2016, she had no idea that she would one day become the subject of one of his books. Mr. Murray accepted her Facebook friend request, and after quietly following her life through her posts, he turned his admiration into a 235-page novel. In 2018, Mr. Murray broke his silence by sending Ms. Stevenson the email that sparked their own love story. The couple were married on April 30.

headline: With a lottery wheel and gold lamé, California selected its first vaccinated prize winners.
text: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California kicked off the state’s Covid-19 vaccine lottery on Friday, drawing the first batch of $50,000 winners on a livestream.

headline: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
text: After a year’s delay, the opening ceremony for the Tokyo Summer Olympics will take place next month.

headline: What to Watch: Sports Shows
text: You can only watch so much sports on TV. After all, you need time to watch TV shows about sports, like these five series.

headline: As Disasters Worsen, California Looks at Curbing Construction in Risky Areas
text: At the start of wildfire season, California’s insurance regulator has backed sweeping changes to discourage home building in fire-prone areas, including looking at cutting off new construction in those regions from what is often their only source of insurance — the state’s high-risk pool.

headline: To Keep Their Son Alive, They Sleep in Shifts. And Hope a Nurse Shows Up.
text: It was 9 a.m. on a Sunday in May, and Chloe Mead was already worn out.

headline: Democrats, Converted to Filibuster Foes, Are Set to Force the Issue
text: WASHINGTON — When the Senate voted in January 2011 on what was then considered an outlandish proposal to allow a simple majority of senators to break filibusters, only a dozen Democrats backed the plan, which went down in a flamingly lopsided vote.

headline: After a ‘Terrible Silence,’ Many of N.Y.C.’s Subway Musicians Are Back
text: Sean Grissom hit the stage — the 28th Street stop on the No. 6 train — promptly at noon on Friday and played the first notes on his cello just as a clattering train barreled past him and drowned out the music with a deafening screech.

headline: Facebook, Jobs, Tom Hanks: Your Friday Evening Briefing
text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Newsom Announces First Winners of Vaccine Lottery
text: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California hosted a game show-style drawing on Friday to announce the first batch of $50,000 winners for the state’s Covid-19 vaccine lottery.

headline: Should I Tuck or Untuck My Shirt?
text: First of all, I wouldn’t say skinny jeans are out of fashion. I’d say other styles are rising in popularity and maybe getting most of the attention. But if you want to wear skinny jeans, you should feel free to do so in complete confidence that no one is going to shriek “Passé!” These days, it’s pretty much anything goes.

headline: What Does Justice Look Like?
text: Hi everyone, welcome to Friday and welcome to summer. Tell us: What do you want to listen to on your summer road trip, or while you’re on a hike or lying on the beach? We’re open to show requests (no promises, but we always love to hear what you’re curious about).

headline: Friederike Mayröcker, Grande Dame in German Literature, Dies at 96
text: Friederike Mayröcker, who was among the most influential and decorated German-language poets of the postwar period, died on Friday in Vienna. She was 96.

headline: Two big banks resume political giving, paused after the Capitol riot.
text: Two major banks that paused their corporate political giving after the U.S. Capitol riot on Jan. 6 are resuming their donations — but with new parameters.

headline: Ganga Stone, Who Gave Sustenance to AIDS Patients, Dies at 79
text: Ganga Stone, who survived on odd jobs in Manhattan until she discovered that her life’s mission was to bring free homemade meals to bedridden AIDS patients on her bicycle, then expanded her volunteer corps of cooks and couriers into an enduring organization called God’s Love We Deliver, died on Wednesday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. She was 79.

headline: Drake Bell Charged With Attempted Child Endangerment
text: Jared Drake Bell, a former star of the Nickelodeon sitcom “Drake & Josh,” was charged in Cleveland with attempted child endangerment and disseminating material harmful to children.

headline: Was the Jobs Report Good? It’s in the Eye of the Beholder.
text: How smoothly is the economy recovering? And was President Biden smart to sign one of the largest spending packages in U.S. history in an effort to help workers — or did it cause only complacency, preventing people from returning to work and holding back the recovery?

headline: McGahn Breaks Little New Ground in Closed-Door Testimony
text: WASHINGTON — Donald F. McGahn II, the former White House counsel, answered detailed questions from Congress behind closed doors on Friday about President Donald J. Trump’s efforts to impede the Russia investigation. But Mr. McGahn provided few new revelations, according to people familiar with his testimony.

headline: After Kamloops Discovery, Indigenous Music Summit Refocuses
text: It’s been impossible to avoid the sadness and shock descended on Canada following the horrific discovery of remains by the Tk’emlups te Secwepemc First Nation at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.

headline: In Delaware, Biden Indulges One of His Oldest Habits: Commuting
text: REHOBOTH BEACH, Del. — Everyone here has a Biden story.

headline: When Living in California Means Fearing the Outdoors
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It’s early June, and the weeds have been brown for weeks.

headline: Making Waves
text: Nearly 20 years later, after I started surfing, I finally have a core group of mostly Black women I surf with.

headline: White House Embraces Job Growth but Distances Itself From Expanded Benefits
text: With fresh data showing that American employers added jobs at a decent but unexceptional pace in May, President Biden on Friday emphasized that his administration would not try to extend enhanced unemployment benefits that Republicans have criticized as a key factor in fueling a labor shortage.

headline: Serena Williams Serves and Scraps Her Way Into the Fourth Round
text: PARIS — Serena Williams’s tennis dress was green and billowed in the breeze. The tape on her right thigh was white and tight.

headline: Patrick Sky, ’60s Folk Star and Later a Piper, Dies at 80
text: Patrick Sky, who established himself as part of the Greenwich Village folk scene of the mid-1960s with smooth guitar-picking and a Southern twang that could be melodic or sassy, then became adept at playing, and making, the notoriously difficult instrument known as the uilleann pipes, died on May 26 in Asheville, N.C. He was 80.

headline: At U.S. Women’s Open, a 17-Year-Old Amateur Puts Herself in Contention
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The first time Megha Ganne competed on one of the world’s most renowned golf courses, her audience included the two-time major winner Martin Kaymer, a former men’s world No. 1. It was at the 2015 finals of the Drive, Chip and Putt contest at Augusta National, and Kaymer was on the range when an 11-year-old Ganne hit her first drive.

headline: Black Lives Matter Has Grown More Powerful, and More Divided
text: In the year since George Floyd was murdered, racial justice organizations across the country have been inundated with millions of dollars in donations and thousands of eager new activists. They have earned a prominent platform that puts them on the front lines of political and social battles.

headline: F.B.I. Director Compares Danger of Ransomware to 9/11 Terror Threat
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is sounding increasingly urgent alarms about high-profile ransomware attacks that have caused widespread gas shortages, shut meat processing plants and paralyzed hospitals, as officials step up efforts to counter cyberthreats.

headline: 1,500 Eggs Were Waiting to Hatch. Then a Drone Crashed.
text: Every April, thousands of elegant terns migrating from Central and South America nest in the sands of the Bolsa Chica Ecological Reserve, one of the last remaining protected coastal wetlands in Southern California.

headline: Florida will no longer publish daily coronavirus reports.
text: The Florida Department of Health will no longer update its Covid-19 dashboard and will suspend daily case and vaccine reports, the governor’s office confirmed on Friday. Officials will instead post weekly updates, becoming the first U.S. state to move to such an infrequent publishing schedule.

headline: That Brooks Koepka Feud Won’t Leave Bryson DeChambeau Alone
text: DUBLIN, OHIO — Bryson DeChambeau and Jordan Spieth played together in the first two rounds of the Memorial Tournament on Thursday and Friday, an arrangement that would starkly demonstrate how two top golfers, both 27, have developed such disparate followings in the sport.

headline: Climactic Court Moment
text: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Just when I think they’ve run out of ways to outwit me, a constructor like Peter Wentz comes along with a beguiling grid like this one, so straightforward-looking at the end, after so much deliberation (and so many mistakes!). I enjoyed the solve immensely but kept tripping over my two left feet — watching the French Open while scratching my head over a tennis pun, that kind of thing.

headline: U.S. Waged Secret Legal Battle to Obtain Emails of 4 Times Reporters
text: WASHINGTON — In the last weeks of the Trump administration and continuing under President Biden, the Justice Department fought a secret legal battle to obtain the email logs of four New York Times reporters in a hunt for their sources, a top lawyer for the newspaper said Friday night.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hong Kong Finds Its Ways to Honor Tiananmen
text: “If you can step out now and take this one small step and see each other, I think this will boost the movement.”

headline: Corrections: June 5, 2021
text: An article on Thursday about a mass shooting at a San Jose Rail Yard misidentified the area of San Jose, Calif., where Samuel Cassidy lived. His house was several blocks west of Highway 101, not in the Evergreen neighborhood. The error was repeated in an article on Friday about the gunman.

headline: Federal Judge Overturns California’s 32-Year Assault Weapons Ban
text: A federal judge in California on Friday overturned the state’s three-decade-old ban on assault weapons, which he called a “failed experiment,” prompting a sharp retort from the state’s governor.

headline: The Best Investment of All: The People You Love the Most
text: In early 2013, three years after the unexpected death of her husband, Chanel Reynolds posted a warning to those who had neglected the bonds that ought to matter most.

headline: Election in East Germany Will Test the Far Right’s Power
text: BERLIN — Five years ago, the nationalist Alternative for Germany sent the country’s traditional parties scrambling when it finished just behind Chancellor Angela Merkel’s conservatives in the regional vote in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt, an ominous portent of the far right’s growing allure.

headline: Essential Quality Wins the 153rd Belmont Stakes
text: As was the case for the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, it was a gorgeous day at Belmont Park on Saturday — the sun was shining, the track was fast, and after a year away because of the coronavirus pandemic, the crowd was more joyful than inebriated. It was a trifecta of perfect conditions for the Belmont Stakes, one of horse racing’s most cherished showcases.

headline: Kamala Harris and a High-Risk, High-Reward Presidential Résumé
text: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.

headline: Naomi Osaka and the Language of Fame
text: Who lost what, exactly, when Naomi Osaka announced she wouldn’t participate in news conferences at the French Open last week, citing her mental health?

headline: As Life Slowed Down, They Got Creative
text: The actor and comedian Niecy Nash and the musician Jessica Betts married Aug. 29, 2020, at the peak of the pandemic, in an intimate ceremony at their home in Ventura County, Calif.

headline: How the World Learns About Bosses Behaving Badly
text: The last thing Debbie Kosta wanted was to talk to a reporter. The past year had already upended her life, with the coronavirus putting her in a coma for nearly a month. When she tried to ease back into her job as a saleswoman at Robbins Research International, the company run by the motivational speaker Tony Robbins, she said she found that the company had locked her out of its systems.

headline: Symone Is a Love Letter to Blackness and Queerness
text: For years, Symone — the drag queen persona created by Reggie Gavin — has been collecting folders of memorable looks, with hundreds of references to Black women. There are photographs from Vogue and Harper’s Bazaar of Lil’ Kim, Whitney Houston, Grace Jones, Diana Ross, Tina Turner and Rihanna.

headline: The End of the Wonder Rug
text: EDEN, N.C. — Sounds change with the seasons, of course, but this spring, among the usual mix of bird song and lawn mowers, there are notable silences in this town of 15,000 people.

headline: Federal Unemployment Aid Is Now a Political Lightning Rod
text: Of the more than four million people whose jobless benefits are going to be cut off in the next few weeks, Bre Starr will be among the first.

headline: Two Days, 100 Florists, 1 Million Flowers: A Festival Blooms in N.Y.C.
text: Florists, like many other small businesses, suffered financially during the worst of the pandemic.

headline: As Vaccines Turn Pandemic’s Tide, U.S. and Europe Diverge on Path Forward
text: LONDON — Over Memorial Day weekend, 135,000 people jammed the oval at the Indianapolis 500. Restaurants across the United States were thronged with customers as mask mandates were being discarded.

headline: Are We Waiting for Everyone to Get Hacked?
text: MONTEREY, Calif. — Leon Panetta is one of the few American government officials who can look around at the nation’s rolling cyberdisasters and justifiably say, “I told you so.”

headline: Pandemic or Not, Proms Are Back
text: As in any other year, teenage girls in California stepped out of salons, only to sit in front of mirrors at home carefully rearranging their coifs.

headline: Meet the People Who Make New York City’s Summer Hustle Happen
text: Like the merciful cracking-open of a fire hydrant on a scalding day, summer promises to be that long-awaited relief for New York. Vaccines are here, many masks are off and there is a growing sense among some  — though not all  — that the city’s inching back to normal.

headline: After Lavish Nights of Clubbing in Bangkok, a Covid Outbreak
text: BANGKOK — When the V.V.I.P. customers disembarked from their limousines at the Krystal Exclusive Club in Bangkok, young women in tiaras, angel wings and not much else sometimes greeted them.

headline: Red Knots in Steepest Decline in Years, Threatening the Species’ Survival
text: The number of red knots visiting the Delaware Bay beaches during this spring’s northbound migration unexpectedly dropped to its lowest since tallies began almost 40 years ago, deepening concern about the shorebird’s survival and dealing a sharp setback to a quarter-century of efforts to save it.

headline: Microsoft’s Bing Briefly Blocked ‘Tank Man’ on Tiananmen Anniversary
text: Microsoft’s Bing search engine briefly blocked images and videos of the famous “tank man” of Tiananmen Square on Friday, the anniversary of China’s massacre of pro-democracy protesters in 1989, in what the company said was an error.

headline: Finance Leaders Reach Global Tax Deal Aimed at Ending Profit Shifting
text: LONDON — The top economic officials from the world’s advanced economies reached a breakthrough on Saturday in their yearslong efforts to overhaul international tax laws, unveiling a broad agreement that aims to stop large multinational companies from seeking out tax havens and force them to pay more of their income to governments.

headline: Olympics Gave Hope to Japan’s L.G.B.T.Q. Activists. But Old Prejudices Die Hard.
text: TOKYO — When Fumino Sugiyama, then a fencer for the Japan women’s national team, decided to come out to one of his coaches as a transgender man, he wasn’t sure what to expect.

headline: On Voting Rights, It Can Cost Companies to Take Both Sides
text: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

headline: Tensions Rise in Memphis as Slave Trader’s Remains Are Removed
text: Traditionally, Memphis residents celebrate Juneteenth at Robert R. Church Park, named for the city’s first Black millionaire.

headline: Why A.I. Should Be Afraid of Us
text: Artificial intelligence is gradually catching up to ours. A.I. algorithms can now consistently beat us at chess, poker and multiplayer video games, generate images of human faces indistinguishable from real ones, write news articles (not this one!) and even love stories, and drive cars better than most teenagers do.

headline: Nigeria Bans Twitter After President’s Tweet Is Deleted
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Nigeria has blocked Twitter after the social media site deleted a tweet by President Muhammadu Buhari that threatened secessionist groups in the southeast who had been responsible for attacks on government offices.

headline: More Than 100 People Killed in Attack in Burkina Faso
text: Armed assailants killed more than 100 people in an attack on a village in northern Burkina Faso, the government said on Saturday, burning houses and leaving many more injured in one of the deadliest assaults the West African nation has seen in years.

headline: Blinded by Brighter Headlights? It’s Not Your Imagination.
text: The light-emitting diodes in the headlights of oncoming traffic became so intense for Shawn DeVries that he started habitually closing his left eye and keeping his right one open as he drove.

headline: Hong Kong dangles incentives, like a free apartment, to entice people to get vaccinated.
text: A brand-new apartment. Paid leave. A private party on a commercial plane.

headline: At Once Diminished and Dominating, Trump Begins His Next Act
text: GREENVILLE, N.C. — Donald J. Trump, the former president of the United States, commutes to New York City from his New Jersey golf club to work out of his office in Trump Tower at least once a week, slipping in and out of Manhattan without attracting much attention.

headline: ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Dissident Denied Food and Medicine in Prison, Family Says
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Paul Rusesabagina, the prominent dissident who was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated movie “Hotel Rwanda,” is being denied food and medicine in a prison in Rwanda where he is being held on terrorism-related charges, according to his family, lawyers and foundation, even as the 66-year-old has complained of poor health.

headline: Meadows Pressed Justice Dept. to Investigate Election Fraud Claims
text: WASHINGTON — In Donald J. Trump’s final weeks in office, Mark Meadows, his chief of staff, repeatedly pushed the Justice Department to investigate unfounded conspiracy theories about the 2020 presidential election, according to newly uncovered emails provided to Congress, portions of which were reviewed by The New York Times.

headline: Can My Co-op Control When I Install My Air-Conditioners?
text: Q: My co-op has a new air-conditioner rule: Once we install units in our windows, we’re not allowed to remove them at the end of the season. Instead, we have to keep them installed year-round. Shareholders who don’t comply will face penalties. When I spoke to the board president, he said, “It’s a New York City law, and if we get a fine from the city, we’re going to fine you.” I looked for applicable laws and found nothing other than safety rules for window air-conditioners. Can our co-op make this a requirement and impose fines?

headline: Let’s Hear It for Sponge Cake!
text: If you’re on the hunt for a light, versatile and summery dessert — maybe for a picnic, or for a Gemini’s birthday — Claire Saffitz has you covered. Her streamlined sponge cake and dreamy strawberry and cream layer cake (above), which makes use of the sponge cake recipe, were among the most popular recipes on New York Times Cooking this week. Either would be a great way to follow up David Tanis’s grilled shrimp skewers with roasted red pepper sauce, or Yasmin Fahr’s spicy shrimp and chickpea salad.

headline: E.T., Phone Me!
text: WASHINGTON — There are plenty of unexplained phenomena here on Earth.

headline: Let’s Celebrate a Lower Birthrate, Not Lament It
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Doctor’s Call to Return to the Activities You Love
text: When the Covid-19 pandemic broke out in the United States, I stopped eating, stopped sleeping and stopped exercising. I stopped making music — a lifelong passion — and even stopped listening to music. I ceased to have pleasure in my life, but I was not depressed. As an emergency physician and a writer, I was filled with intense energy and focus.

headline: A Supreme Court Case Poses a Threat to L.G.B.T.Q. Foster Kids
text: The Supreme Court is expected to rule this month on a case that could upend, in the name of religious freedom, 50 years of progress in the effort to provide better support for L.G.B.T.Q. children in the foster system. Such a decision would be a devastating setback for all children in foster care and set a dangerous precedent that could have broad repercussions.

headline: Photos from the Belmont Stakes
text: The Belmont Stakes returned to more of its normal traditions this year amid the coronavirus pandemic; its usual mile-and-a-half distance was restored and so was its traditional standing on the calendar as the final leg of the Triple Crown. Fans were also back — 11,238, organizers said — to watch Essential Quality take the win over Hot Rod Charlie.

headline: Sinkholes, Collapsing Canal Walls, Rickety Bridges: Amsterdam Is Crumbling
text: It was a rainy evening in April when Marlies Pinksterboer, an Amsterdam-based jewelry designer, was startled by a loud, rumbling sound. “It was as if a part of a building had come crashing down,” she said. “It was crazy.”

headline: Variety: Acrostic
text: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt comes from a much-loved, best-selling travel book from the 1980s, “Blue Highways,” which is the first book in a trilogy by William Least Heat-Moon. It’s so named because on old American maps, main roads are red lines, back ways blue. I read one of the trilogy’s books for a class in college way back when, and I can recommend them to you if you’re thinking about hitting the road this summer (which I imagine a lot of us are) — Heat-Moon creates a world where you are a traveler, not a tourist, through vibrant terrain.

headline: Floyd Mayweather vs. Logan Paul: Is It a Fight? ‘It’s Entertainment’
text: The notion of this Sunday’s boxing spectacle between Floyd Mayweather Jr. and Logan Paul didn’t begin because there was an obvious title at stake, or as the natural culmination of a long-simmering rivalry, but as an out-of-nowhere suggestion.

headline: Workers Are Gaining Leverage Over Employers Right Before Our Eyes
text: The relationship between American businesses and their employees is undergoing a profound shift: For the first time in a generation, workers are gaining the upper hand.

headline: Yoshi Wada, Inventive Creator of Sound Worlds, Dies at 77
text: Yoshi Wada, a Japanese-born composer and artist who drew a following creating cacophonous, minimalist performances on homemade instruments and was a member of the Fluxus performance art movement that took root in New York in the 1960s, died on May 18 at his home in Manhattan. He was 77.

headline: Before the pandemic, many states had anti-mask laws on the books. Repealing them could be a challenge.
text: Long before the pandemic arrived on American shores, there were debates over the politics of mask wearing. More than a dozen states have laws barring people from covering their faces in public, most of them ordinances passed to deter the Ku Klux Klan hate group.

headline: White House Disavows Knowledge of Gag Order on Times Leaders in Leak Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said on Saturday that no one at the White House had been aware that the Justice Department was seeking to seize the email data of four New York Times reporters and had obtained a gag order in March barring a handful of newspaper executives who knew about the fight from discussing it.

headline: Cancel Culture Works. We Wouldn’t Have Marriage Equality Without It.
text: Anyone looking to understand how same-sex marriage went from legal in one state to the law of the land a decade later should not overlook the small crowd that gathered outside San Diego’s Manchester Grand Hyatt hotel just past noon one Friday in July 2008, holding signs that said, “The Hyatt of hypocrisy.”

headline: Richard Rubenstein, 97, Dies; Theologian Challenged Ideas of God
text: Richard L. Rubenstein, the leading Jewish voice in the theological groundswell of the 1960s known as the “Death of God” movement, who argued that the Holocaust had invalidated the idea of an omnipotent, benevolent deity who safeguards Jews as the chosen people, died on May 16 in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 97.

headline: Three Paths to Containing Trump
text: Last fall and winter, the president of the United States attempted, with ineffectual strategy but violent consequences, to pressure Republicans to overturn an election that he quite clearly lost. Now he reportedly believes that swing-state “audits” will somehow reinstall him in the White House by the end of summer. Many of the courtiers who encouraged his earlier delusions are still busily at work; one of them, Michael Flynn, recently suggested (before backpedaling) that the United States needed a Myanmar-style military coup.

headline: Kamala Harris Can’t Win
text: Frank Bruni will stop writing regular Opinion columns in late June, but his popular weekly newsletter will live on. To keep up with his political analysis, cultural commentary and personal reflections, sign up here.

headline: Turning Child Care Into a New Cold War
text: For a country brimming with “pro-family” politicians, the United States sure is a tough place to raise a family.

headline: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Endorses Maya Wiley for N.Y.C. Mayor
text: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, one of the most prominent left-wing leaders in the country, endorsed Maya D. Wiley in the race for New York City mayor on Saturday, urging voters to “come together as a movement.”

headline: Thousands Descend on Miami to Glorify Bitcoin
text: MIAMI — There was money in the air. Buzzwords floated around, like NFT, BTD, blockchain, token. There was a frenzied energy.

headline: Alzheimer’s Drug Poses a Dilemma for the F.D.A.
text: The Food and Drug Administration is on the verge of announcing one of its most contentious decisions in years: the fate of an Alzheimer’s drug that could be the first treatment approved after nearly two decades of failed efforts to find ways to curb the debilitating disease.

headline: 2021 French Open: What to Watch on Sunday
text: How to watch: 5 a.m. to noon Eastern time on the Tennis Channel, noon to 2 p.m. on NBC and 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. on Peacock; streaming on the Tennis Channel+ and Peacock apps.

headline: Raymond Donovan, 90, Dies; Labor Secretary Quit Under a Cloud
text: Raymond J. Donovan, who resigned as labor secretary in the Reagan administration while facing criminal charges of having earlier schemed to defraud New York City of millions of dollars when he was a New Jersey construction company executive — charges of which he was acquitted by a jury — died on Wednesday at his home in New Vernon, N.J. He was 90.

headline: School District Agrees to Pay $3 Million After a Bullied Boy, 8, Killed Himself
text: For at least a year, Gabriel Taye, 8, was severely bullied at his elementary school in Cincinnati.

headline: Olio
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Solving a Robyn Weintraub grid is always a happy adventure, isn’t it? I was thrilled to see her byline today, amazed that this is her first appearance on a Sunday, and not disappointed in the slightest to gradually realize that we have a themeless extravaganza, nothing but irrepressible, bright verbiage from start to finish.

headline: Ferry Runs Aground in Brooklyn, Injuring a Crew Member
text: One crew member was injured and more than 100 passengers were evacuated after a ferry ran aground near the shoreline of Bushwick Inlet Park in Brooklyn on Saturday afternoon, police and fire officials said.

headline: Coco Gauff Catches a Break as Her French Open Run Continues
text: PARIS — Coco Gauff has already played in the second week at Roland Garros. The junior tournaments are held during that period, and she won the French Open girls title here in 2018.

headline: Ferry Carrying 100 Passengers Runs Aground in Brooklyn
text: Passengers were evacuated from the Seastreak ferry on Saturday after it ran aground near Bushwick Inlet Park. One crew member was injured.

headline: A Gun Rights Win in California With Sights Set on the Supreme Court
text: SACRAMENTO — In 1989, a gunman’s three-minute rampage killed five children at a Stockton, Calif., elementary school and wounded some 30 students and teachers. The resulting shock and outrage gave rise to the nation’s first state ban on assault weapons, signed by a Republican governor.

headline: John M. Patterson, Segregationist Alabama Governor, Dies at 99
text: John M. Patterson, a defiant segregationist who defeated and preceded George C. Wallace as the governor of Alabama as the South plunged into the violence and turmoil of the civil rights movement in the late 1950s and ’60s, died on Friday at his home in Goldville, Ala. He was 99.

headline: Federer Escapes With a Win in a French Open Night Match
text: PARIS — In a third-round night match that ended at 12:45 a.m. Sunday in a nearly empty center court, Roger Federer managed to summon the energy and inspiration to hold off Dominik Koepfer, 7-6 (5), 6-7 (3), 7-6 (4), 7-5.

headline: Jon Rahm Withdraws From Memorial Tournament After Positive Coronavirus Test
text: DUBLIN, OHIO — Jon Rahm, a popular player on the PGA Tour and the world’s third-ranked male golfer, had just charged to a six-stroke lead on Saturday in the third round of the Memorial Tournament, an event he won a year ago. Walking from the 18th hole, where a crowd surrounding the green showered him with warm applause, Rahm, 26, shook hands with his playing partners and smiled.

headline: Corrections: June 6, 2021
text: Because of an editing error, a Metropolitan Diary item this weekend about a bike ride in Riverdale misstates the author’s surnames. He is Malcolm-Wiley Floyd, not Ford.

headline: Boy, 10, Killed in Queens Shooting That Mayor Calls ‘a Coward’s Act’
text: Justin Wallace’s 11th birthday was fast approaching, and the soon-to-be sixth grader was eagerly planning a celebration that included a trip to an amusement park and a buffet.

headline: With Pride on the Line, U.S.A. Baseball Qualifies for Olympics
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — After firing the ball across the diamond for the final out of a 4-2 win over Venezuela, United States third baseman Todd Frazier found closer David Robertson near the mound and wrapped him in a hug. Soon, the entire team huddled on the infield at Clover Park, bouncing up and down, yelling and spraying alcohol as if they had won a championship.

headline: ‘I Wasn’t Quite Finished With the Cigarette When My Car Pulled Up’
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Biden Is Embracing Europe, but Then What? NATO and the E.U. Have Concerns.
text: BRUSSELS — Four years ago, European leaders were traumatized by President Donald J. Trump, who cheered Brexit and eviscerated NATO, declaring the alliance “obsolete,” calling member countries deadbeats and at first refusing to explicitly endorse NATO’s bedrock mutual defense principle.

headline: These Catholic Parishes Welcome New York’s L.G.B.T.Q. Community
text: The pews fill up quickly each Sunday at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, a Roman Catholic parish in Midtown Manhattan, with worshipers who travel from all corners of the city to attend what it markets as its gay-friendly 5 p.m. Mass.

headline: U.S. Aid to Central America Hasn’t Slowed Migration. Can Kamala Harris?
text: SAN ANTONIO HUISTA, Guatemala — An American contractor went to a small town in the Guatemalan mountains with an ambitious goal: to ignite the local economy, and hopefully even persuade people not to migrate north to the United States.

headline: The Cost of Being an ‘Interchangeable Asian’
text: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

headline: Martina Navratilova Has Plenty to Say
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Martina Navratilova sat at a dockside restaurant in Florida this spring, wearing worn-out jeans, a denim button-down shirt that hung loosely at her waist and a 1619 cap that one of her five dogs had gnawed on. It’s her favorite hat these days.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Still a Pioneer at 64, Navratilova Has Plenty on Her Mind
text: “I lived behind the Iron Curtain. You really think you are going to be able to tell me to keep my mouth shut?”

headline: ‘Fear and Vigilance’: Israel’s Ultra-Orthodox Face a Fall from Power
text: JERUSALEM — Still reeling from bearing the brunt of Israel’s coronavirus pandemic, then a deadly stampede at a religious festival, Israel’s ultra-Orthodox Jews now face the prospect of losing the power they have wielded in government — a setback that could relax some of the strictures on life in Israel.

headline: How Did a Gay Scientist of Jewish Descent Thrive Under the Nazis?

headline: The Greatest Draft Pick Ever

headline: A Federal College Loan Program Can Trap Parents in Debt
text: Kate Schweizer and her husband didn’t want their two daughters, just 13 months apart, to begin their adult lives saddled with college debt, so they borrowed much of the money themselves. Beginning in 2005, the couple took out a new batch of federal loans each academic year, eventually accumulating about $220,000 in debt.

headline: In Praise of Patrick Wilson, Scream King
text: Ed Warren is sitting in a musty living room in North London, trying to establish contact with a demon. Behind him sits a little girl, said to be possessed. The demon won’t talk, she insists, unless he faces away and gives him some privacy. With his back to the girl, Ed gets down to business. “Now come on out and talk to us,” he says brightly.

headline: Wedding Receptions Are Back, and Italy’s Candy Makers Are Delighted
text: SULMONA, Italy — Workers ladled sugar water on the almonds roasting in spinning copper basins. They set them to tumble hypnotically in tubs of chocolate, collected the confections spit out of packaging machines and loaded white, blue, pink and green varieties onto crates.

headline: Manchin Vows to Block Democratic Voting Rights Bill and Preserve Filibuster
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia said on Sunday in no uncertain terms that he would not vote for the Democrats’ far-reaching bill to combat voter suppression, nor would he ever end the legislative filibuster, a written promise that imperils much of President Biden’s agenda.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. Eric Kim did valuable work for The Times this week, breaking down the science of and techniques for making juicy chicken breasts, instead of the unfortunately more common bone-dry ones. It’s a satisfying read (with an excellent use of the compound noun “noun cluster” in it) and deeply informative.

headline: Cholera ‘Forever Destroyed’ U.N.’s Image in Haiti, Ban Ki-moon Says
text: Respect for the United Nations in Haiti was “forever destroyed” by the cholera epidemic that ravaged the impoverished country after the 2010 earthquake, the leader of the global organization during that period said in a new book.

headline: Despite It All, López Obrador Has My Vote

headline: A Psychiatrist Invited to Yale Spoke of Fantasies of Shooting White People
text: A psychiatrist said in a lecture at Yale University’s School of Medicine that she had fantasies of shooting white people, prompting the university to later restrict online access to her expletive-filled talk, which it said was “antithetical to the values of the school.”

headline: New York Turns to Smart Thermometers for Disease Detection in Schools

headline: Harry and Meghan Announce Birth of Second Baby, Lilibet Diana

headline: Graeme Ferguson, Filmmaker Who Helped Create Imax, Dies at 91
text: Graeme Ferguson, a Canadian documentarian who cocreated Imax, the panoramic cinema experience that immerses audiences in movies, and was the chief creative force of the company for years, died on May 8 at his home in Lake of Bays, Ontario. He was 91.

headline: Republicans, Don’t Ignore the Evidence on ‘Labor Shortages’
text: Talk of labor shortages is everywhere. That is to say, many economic commentators and policymakers have been bemoaning the supposedly alarming reports of a lack of workers to fill the jobs vital to the continuing economic recovery. But there is always a chorus of employers complaining they can’t find the workers they need. We have to look beyond anecdotal reports to fully understand the data.

headline: Once a Bastion of Free Speech, the A.C.L.U. Faces an Identity Crisis
text: It was supposed to be the celebration of a grand career, as the American Civil Liberties Union presented a prestigious award to the longtime lawyer David Goldberger. He had argued one of its most famous cases, defending the free speech rights of Nazis in the 1970s to march in Skokie, Ill., home to many Holocaust survivors.

headline: Mississippi has the country’s lowest vaccination rates. The governor says that’s not a problem.
text: Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi on Sunday said that despite his state’s relatively low vaccination rates, case numbers showed there was no longer a high risk of contracting or being hospitalized with Covid-19.

headline: How Lin-Manuel Miranda and Friends Made an Old Bookstore New

It starts with ancient Greek texts and, 2,400 volumes later, spills into a pile that includes “Summer: The Donna Summer Musical.”

headline: T.B. Joshua, Nigerian Celebrity Megachurch Pastor, Dies at 57
text: DAKAR, Senegal — Temitope Balogun Joshua, known as T.B., founded the Synagogue Church of All Nations in Nigeria and one of the most popular and controversial evangelical pastors in Africa, died on Saturday. He was 57.

headline: British tourists scramble to return from Portugal to meet a new quarantine deadline.

headline: Student Is Denied High School Diploma for Wearing Mexican Flag

headline: Yellen Won a Global Tax Deal. Now Comes the Hard Part.

headline: The N.B.A. Playoffs Yield Several Injured Stars and No Clear Favorite

The Miami Heat, who stretched James and his Los Angeles Lakers to six games before losing last year’s N.B.A. finals, were swept by the Milwaukee Bucks.

headline: This bout is an exhibition — with heavily modified rules.
text: There will be a stark size difference when the fighters enter the ring. Floyd Mayweather Jr. is 5 feet 8 inches tall and normally fights around 150 pounds. Logan Paul is 6 inches taller and officially weighed 199.4 pounds in his first professional fight. When the fighters weighed in on Saturday, there was a nearly 35-pound difference: Mayweather weighed 155 pounds and Paul weighed 189.5.

headline: Here’s how both Mayweather and Paul built up their fame.
text: Floyd Mayweather Jr., 44, is viewed as one of the greatest boxers of all time, known for his evasive style and for suffering minimal damage in fights. He turned professional at 19 and needed only two years to win his first title. Notable opponents he has faced include Oscar De La Hoya, Canelo Álvarez and Manny Pacquiao.

headline: Here’s how to watch the fight.
text: The Floyd Mayweather Jr.-Logan Paul exhibition fight is scheduled for Sunday night at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Fla. The pay-per-view card starts at 8 p.m. Eastern, which you can purchase for $49.99 on Showtime or Fanmio to watch on television or stream through a computer or mobile device.

headline: Sweet Cherries, Bitter Politics: Two Farm Stands and the Nation’s Divides

It presents a concentrated opportunity to be seen, in jubilation and triumph, to recognize the struggles, to commemorate the fallen and to honor the progress.

headline: Patrick Cantlay Wins the Memorial Tournament in a One-Hole Playoff
text: DUBLIN, Ohio — The leaderboards positioned at critical junctures of a professional golf tournament are more than scoreboards. headline: U.S. Women’s Open: Yuka Saso Wins, Extending a Majors Drought by Americans
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Yuka Saso of the Philippines bent her leg like a flamingo, using her body language to will in the birdie putt. It was the first playoff hole after Saso and Nasa Hataoka of Japan finished 72 holes of the 76th United States Women’s Open on Sunday tied at four-under 280, one stroke better than the third-round leader, the American Lexi Thompson.

headline: Anthony Weiner’s Not Coming Back. But He Has Nowhere to Go.

headline: What Happened When Trump Was Banned on Social Media
text: Since Facebook and Twitter banned him, Donald J. Trump, the former president, has posted statements online far less often. But some of his statements have traveled just as far and wide on social networks.

headline: Why the Latest Republican Assault on L.G.B.T.Q. Rights Is Different
text: Last month, Gov. Bill Lee of Tennessee signed into law a discriminatory bill to prevent transgender people from using restrooms aligning with their gender identity at any business or place of public accommodation. A few days earlier, Governor Lee signed an anti-transgender student bathroom bill, too. These are the first bathroom bills to be enacted since North Carolina’s notorious HB2 in 2016.

headline: Don’t Kill Remote Learning. Black and Brown Families Need It.
text: Remote instruction. Virtual learning. School-by-Zoom. Whatever you want to call it, it has kept this Black man — along with my wife and 7-year-old son — safe from Covid over the last year, even if it hasn’t been easy on anyone. Each day, as my son sits at his desk in our home near Washington learning about bar graphs on a laptop screen, I am comforted by the knowledge that he’s not sitting in a poorly ventilated classroom at risk of getting sick.

headline: See You in 2022: Wary New Yorkers Are Delaying Celebrations Again

headline: Think Twice Before Helping That Baby Bird You Found
text: NASHVILLE — My whole family was in the yard on Memorial Day when my middle son noticed something small and gray balanced on the trunk of his brother’s car, which was parked just off the driveway under a large white pine. It was a baby bird — a wee baby bird, partly bald and partly fuzzy, hardly bigger than a quarter. Far too young to be out of the nest.

headline: Silicon Valley’s Thin Skins and Giant Egos

headline: From Doomsday Preppers to Doomsday Plotters

White-power groups in the United States have long promised a catastrophic race war. And in Germany and Austria, neo-Nazis herald an imagined putsch on “Day X” — when the democratic order collapses and they take over.

headline: In Arizona 2020 Election Review, Risks for Republicans, and Democracy

By April, it had become the dominant variant in the United States, and it has remained so ever since.

A chalet-inspired clubhouse, designed in 1919 by Bernard Maybeck, was restored in 2013 and is available for use by neighborhood residents.

headline: David Dushman, Soviet Soldier Who Helped Liberate Auschwitz, Dies at 98
text: BERLIN — David Dushman, who as a soldier for the Soviet Union drove his tank through the electric fence surrounding the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz on Jan. 27, 1945, and is believed to have been the last surviving liberator of the camp, died in Munich on Saturday. He was 98.

headline: She Was Stabbed and Left in a Cornfield in 1972. Now There’s an Arrest.
text: For nearly 50 years, the murder of Julie Ann Hanson, who was 15 when she was stabbed to death and her body was discovered in a cornfield, baffled investigators in a Chicago suburb.

headline: Telegraph and Mescal Wildfires Force Hundreds of Evacuations
text: Two wildfires, less than 50 miles away from each other, have burned tens of thousands of acres east of Phoenix as of Monday morning.

headline: A New Contemporary Art Museum Aims to Heal a City’s Wounds
text: L’AQUILA, Italy — On a recent sunny morning, things were kicking into high gear in the Piazza Santa Maria Paganica, a square in the central Italian city of L’Aquila. Assorted officials, their entourages, journalists, passers-by and museum staff mingled excitedly in front of a Baroque palazzo, which was about to be opened as Italy’s newest bastion of contemporary art.

headline: Mexico President’s Grip on Congress Slips, Showing Limits of His Mandate
text: MEXICO CITY — Voters in Mexico tapped the brakes on President Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s ambitious plans to overhaul the country’s economy and society by narrowing his leftist coalition’s majority in Congress in midterm elections on Sunday.

headline: Arizona’s election review poses risks for Republicans and Democracy.
text: The Republican State Senate’s autopsy of the 2020 vote, broadly seen as a shambolic, partisan effort to nurse grievances about Donald J. Trump’s loss here in November, risks driving away some of the very people the party needs to win statewide elections in 2022.

headline: Looking to Tackle Prescription Overload
text: The last straw, for Leslie Hawkins, was her mother’s 93rd-birthday gathering in 2018.

headline: As a Tense Summer Looms, Northern Ireland Braces
text: BELFAST, Northern Ireland — The pandemic was hard on David Milliken, who sells drums, flags and pro-British banners from his brightly-colored shop in Sandy Row, a loyalist stronghold in Belfast. But now, he said, “things have started to open up again,” especially since “the unrest is back.”

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Limiting Military Draft to Men
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a challenge to a federal law that requires only men to register for the military draft.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
text: Good morning. It’s funny, what professional food people get up to, cooking at home. I love the celery toasts the chef and writer Gabrielle Hamilton adds to her snack trays, and the tinned fish that leads our restaurant critic, Pete Wells, to declare himself “at least 35 percent sardine.” And I’m a big fan of the potato chip omelet (above) that the chef Ferran Adrià makes for his family, a quicker take on a Spanish tortilla that you can make with supplies picked up at the corner store.

headline: This Summer, Make It Chianti Classico
text: Here’s my wine for the summer: Chianti Classico.

headline: Why Does Disaster Aid Often Favor White People?
text: Roy Vaussine and Charlotte Biagas live in modest, single-story homes about a dozen miles apart in southwest Louisiana. When Hurricane Laura tore through their community last August, the damage was nearly identical. A tree crashed through the roof of each house. Neither had insurance. Each sought help from the federal government.

headline: India’s central government will take over vaccinations amid criticism over its handling of the outbreak.
text: Amid criticism of the government’s handling of one of the world’s deadliest outbreaks, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India said on Monday that the federal government would play a bigger role procuring Covid-19 vaccines on behalf of states. It’s a process that had been mired in confusion because of squabbling between the central and state governments and a lack of vaccine supply.

headline: This Tiny Creature Survived 24,000 Years Frozen in Siberian Permafrost
text: Bdelloid rotifers may be the toughest, tiniest animal you’ve never heard of.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Alzheimer’s Drug Despite Fierce Debate Over Whether It Works
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday approved the first new medication for Alzheimer’s disease in nearly two decades, a contentious decision made despite opposition from the agency’s independent advisory committee and some Alzheimer’s experts who said there was not enough evidence that the drug can help patients.

headline: How Thousands of Indigenous Children Vanished in Canada
text: OTTAWA — The remains of 751 people, mainly Indigenous children, were discovered at the site of a former school in the province of Saskatchewan, a Canadian Indigenous group said on Thursday, shaking a nation grappling with generations of systematic abuse of Indigenous people.

headline: New Dinosaur Species Is Australia’s Largest, Researchers Say
text: Robyn and Stuart Mackenzie, riding motorbikes one day in 2006 on their vast sheep and cattle farm in the Australian outback, spotted a pile of what looked like large black rocks.

text: You will not find the word Concacaffy in any dictionary, but any soccer fan in North America knows what it means and how to use it in a sentence.

headline: The Minister of Chaos
text: Inside the controlled chaos of 10 Downing Street.

headline: Rejecting Biden’s Win, Rising Republicans Attack Legitimacy of Elections
text: A Republican House candidate from Wisconsin says he is appalled by the violence he witnessed at the Jan. 6 rally that turned into the siege at the Capitol. But he did not disagree with G.O.P. lawmakers’ effort to overturn the presidential election results that night.

headline: Gallery Weekend Brings London’s Art Scene Back to Life
text: LONDON — “I met her on a dating app … I met her in a pub,” said Ellie Pennick, 24, director and founder of Guts Gallery, recalling on Friday how she had discovered some of the young artists whose work she was selling from a pop-up space near Carnaby Street during the debut edition of London Gallery Weekend.

headline: The Year We Battled Covid, Revisited

headline: Watch Live: Harris and Guatemalan President Deliver Joint Statements
text: Vice President Kamala Harris speaks alongside President Alejandro Giammattei of Guatemala on her first international trip as vice president. Ms. Harris is visiting Mexico and Guatemala to address reducing migration.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Evermore’ Vaults to No. 1 With a Vinyl Bump
text: On the Friday before Memorial Day, Taylor Swift noted on social media that the vinyl version of her nearly six-month-old album “Evermore” was finally available. Pictured in her post lying in the grass with her LP, Swift informed her fans, “You can get it at your fav indie record store, Target, Walmart & Amazon.”

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Immigrants Seeking Green Cards
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled unanimously on Monday that immigrants allowed to stay in the United States temporarily for humanitarian reasons may not apply for green cards if they had entered the country unlawfully.

headline: N.Y. businesses can choose to end most remaining limits, the governor says.
text: New York will lift most of its remaining pandemic-era restrictions on businesses and social settings once 70 percent of the state’s adults have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Monday.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Will Return to Broadway in June
text: Bruce Springsteen is returning to Broadway.

headline: Police Make Mass Arrests at Protest Against Oil Pipeline
text: PARK RAPIDS, MINN. — The protesters who gathered in the boreal forests of Northern Minnesota came from across the country — Native American tribes and their supporters, environmentalists and religious leaders — all to fight an expansion of Line 3, a $9 billion pipeline operated by the Canadian company, Enbridge, that would carry hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil through Minnesota’s delicate watersheds and tribal lands.

headline: She Was Deeply Moved by Refugees’ Stories. So She Told Them in Song.
text: Diana Jones is known as a singer-songwriter of uncommon empathy, an astute observer of the human condition whose heart goes out to those who suffer and are oppressed.

headline: Women’s Prison Plagued by Sexual Violence Will Close, Governor Says
text: Just over a year ago, the Justice Department offered a scathing indictment of New Jersey’s only prison for women, describing a culture of sexual violence by guards so entrenched that it violated prisoners’ constitutional protections from cruel and unusual punishment.

headline: Republicans win two Texas mayoral races, including one in McAllen, which is 85 percent Hispanic.
text: Republicans in Texas celebrated on Monday after winning two closely watched mayoral elections in the state on Saturday, taking control of cities in Democratic counties.

headline: Journalists at The Atlantic unionize, the latest in a wave of media organizing.
text: The Atlantic intends to voluntarily recognize a newly formed union of editorial workers, the magazine’s editor in chief, Jeffrey Goldberg, said Monday.

headline: In Her New Memoir, Ursula M. Burns Recounts Blazing a Trail to the Top of Xerox
text: There’s a thriving trade in what are sometimes called “executive book summaries.” These are CliffsNotes for the harried managerial class. New business books are crunched down to a few pages of bullet points, so supervisors can consume them on the run.

headline: Both Are Abuse Survivors, but One Can Sue and One Can’t
text: SYRACUSE, N.Y. — After months of video calls and group emails, Robert Druger and Robert Bender agreed to meet for the first time on Memorial Day and revisit the places that had caused so much parallel anguish, four decades ago.

headline: A House Divided: A Palestinian, a Settler and the Struggle for East Jerusalem
text: JERUSALEM — Few places in East Jerusalem show the struggle over the city more intimately than a four-story house on a narrow alley in the Silwan district.

headline: What to Know About Amazon’s New Network
text: If you own a newer Amazon gadget, like a Ring camera or an Echo speaker, you'll be automatically enrolled in a new network called Sidewalk.

headline: Yankees Find Life Without Left-Handed Batters Isn’t Right
text: If this were 2020 — and let’s never go back there, please — the Yankees’ regular season would be over after 60 games. They would still be alive, but eagerly rooting for other teams to lose, allowing them to qualify for the eighth spot in a bloated playoff field.

headline: ‘Bill’s 44th’ Review: Where Are All the Party People?
text: There are shows so delightfully unexpected that you hesitate, when writing about them, to give anything away. “Bill’s 44th” is one of those — a poignant, comic puppet play for grown-ups about a birthday party whose guests fail to appear.

headline: High Heels Are Ready to Stomp Out Crocs and Birks
text: As she dressed for her 26th birthday recently, Cleo Pac Monrose focused on making a statement. Ms. Monrose, a podcast marketer for Spotify, flicked the dust off her party clothes and the high-heeled lavender pumps she had been hoarding since just before lockdown.

headline: In Paris, Rafael Nadal Is the Same as Always, and Yet He’s Different
text: PARIS — His hair is thinning on top. His knees can be shaky. In January, he suddenly came down with a balky back that almost forced him to withdraw from the Australian Open.

headline: Summer’s Greatest Prize: Watermelons, With Seeds, Please
text: In the fervor of June, heirloom watermelon varieties flourish in backyard gardens and family-run microfarms throughout the American South. Their scarlet-colored flesh, stippled with black seeds, is a striking relic of summers past in comparison with the seedless supermarket varieties.

headline: The Sweet Smell of Hipness
text: Glenn O’Brien was the leading boulevardier of my particular subgenerational pocket.

headline: Gripped by ‘Dinner Party-gate,’ Yale Law Confronts a Venomous Divide
text: NEW HAVEN, Conn. — On March 26, a group of students at Yale Law School approached the dean’s office with an unusual accusation: Amy Chua, one of the school’s most popular but polarizing professors, had been hosting drunken dinner parties with students, and possibly federal judges, during the pandemic.

headline: Boko Haram Leader Really Did Kill Himself, Audio Message Says
text: DAKAR, Senegal — The head of Nigeria’s best-known terrorist group, Boko Haram, has been reported dead many times before.

headline: High School Student Fatally Shot Near Soccer Field Where He Excelled
text: Moussa Fofana became enamored with soccer in middle school, honing his skills at all hours, his mother said. The pandemic may have upended his life in other ways over the past academic year, his third in high school, but it could not dim his passion for the game.

headline: Apple unveils new privacy features, digital IDs and changes to FaceTime.
text: Apple once again took aim at the vast digital-advertising industry on Monday and unveiled a number of changes to protect iPhones users’ privacy and strengthen its position as a gatekeeper between consumers and the rest of the digital industry.

headline: Wedding Bells for Two 95-Year-Olds
text: Joy Morrow-Nulton keeps a diary, but she doesn’t need it to remember the date of her first lunch with John Shults Jr. in upstate New York. “It was May 14, 2019, and the restaurant was A Slice of Italy,” Ms. Morrow-Nulton, 95, said. The specifics of their conversation mostly escape her because she was bored. But two years later, she is pleased she pretended otherwise and stuck it out.

headline: 16 Injured After Bus Crashes Into Brooklyn Home
text: Sixteen people were injured, none of them critically, after a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus crashed into a rowhouse in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Amid criticism of the government’s handling of the pandemic, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in a nationwide address that the federal government would play a bigger role in getting vaccines on behalf of states. He also opened free shots up to everyone over 18.

headline: Vermont’s Governor Expands Voting Rights, Bucking Republican Push
text: Gov. Phil Scott of Vermont signed legislation on Monday that requires all registered voters in the state to receive mail-in ballots, an expansion of voting rights that counters a movement among Republicans in other states to restrict them.

headline: Carbon Dioxide in Atmosphere Hits Record High Despite Pandemic Dip
text: The amount of carbon dioxide piling up in Earth’s atmosphere set a record last month, once again reaching the highest levels in human history despite a temporary dip in the burning of fossil fuels worldwide caused by the coronavirus pandemic, scientists said Monday.

headline: Justice Dept. Recovers Millions from Colonial Pipeline Hack
text: The Justice Department said on Monday that it had recovered the majority of the ransom paid to the hackers who shut down the computer systems of the Colonial Pipeline last month.

headline: With Mayweather-Paul Bonanza, Lines Continue to Blur in Combat Sports
text: For an instant on Sunday night, as Logan Paul stood in a boxing ring across Floyd Mayweather Jr., the best boxer of this generation, television cameras and microphones captured his astonishment.
